docs.abstract: The actor on his “double act” movies and what acting and the priesthood have in common.
docs.snippet: The actor on his “double act” movies and what acting and the priesthood have in common.
docs.lead_paragraph: You have four “double act” movies coming out around the same time: “Stan & Ollie,” “Holmes & Watson,” “The Sisters Brothers” and “Ralph Breaks the Internet.” Do you consciously seek out work about duos? I’ve done a lot of stuff where I was the best friend — whether it’s with Will Ferrell in “Step Brothers” or Mark Wahlberg in “Boogie Nights.” That’s a recurring thing in my life too: From the time I was a little kid, I always had a best friend, and I would really heavily invest in single friendships. One of those truly magical things that human beings can do together is to create harmony, to create a third thing that wasn’t there before the two decided to cooperate. So I try to do work that’s bigger than myself. I didn’t become an actor because I have a big ego — I did it because I love collaborating with people. I find it really lonely to work alone, and the pressure is just too great when you have to come up with every idea yourself.

headline.main: John C. Reilly Wants to Play Vulnerable Men
headline.print_headline: John C. Reilly Wants to Play Vulnerable Men

docs.lead_paragraph: Like the run-on title of Blas Falconer’s spare yet luminous poem, the couple driving through the Puerto Rican countryside are suspended in time. Who they are and where they’ll end up is a mystery; we never see the man, and the woman has set her thoughts adrift as memories swirl, unspoken, between them. Inside their traveling capsule, history and fate are immaterial, hovering outside where the road scrolls past — until, in one brilliant stroke, the membrane is pierced, and the interminably vast sorrows of an entire island rush in. Selected by Rita Dove

docs.abstract: At least 152 pro-government forces and 11 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
docs.snippet: At least 152 pro-government forces and 11 civilians were killed in Afghanistan during the past week.
docs.lead_paragraph: The following reports compile all significant security incidents confirmed by New York Times reporters throughout Afghanistan. It is necessarily incomplete as many local officials refuse to confirm casualty information. The toll here does not generally include claims of insurgents killed by the government, because of the difficulty of verifying such claims. Similarly, the reports do not include attacks on the government claimed by the Taliban. Both sides routinely inflate casualties of their opponents.

docs.abstract: The former Senate majority leader on President Trump and Senator Chuck Schumer, and on why he doesn’t regret ending the filibuster for judicial appointments.
docs.snippet: The former Senate majority leader on President Trump and Senator Chuck Schumer, and on why he doesn’t regret ending the filibuster for judicial appointments.
docs.lead_paragraph: Early on the afternoon of Dec. 11, about an hour after an Oval Office meeting between President Trump, the Senate minority leader Chuck Schumer and the incoming House speaker Nancy Pelosi devolved on live TV into a shouting match — a “tinkle contest with a skunk,” in Pelosi’s postgame grandiloquence — I pulled up to a McMansion in a gated community outside Las Vegas. I presented my ID and pre-issued bar-code pass to a security guard. Another guard emerged from a sedan in the driveway, instructed me to leave my rental car across the street and pointed me to the front door.

headline.main: Harry Reid Has a Few Words for Washington

docs.abstract: In the Trump era, the ritual of the state funeral stands in for an increasingly distant past.
docs.snippet: In the Trump era, the ritual of the state funeral stands in for an increasingly distant past.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Thursday morning, as I was walking through downtown Washington and up to Capitol Hill, workers were carting away the last of the metal security barriers that had been erected around the Capitol, where George H.W. Bush lay in state earlier in the week. His coffin was sent off to Houston on Air Force One the previous afternoon, and on the Hill there was a feeling that the circus had left town — or, maybe, the opposite.

headline.main: In Washington, Sending Off the Old Normal
